articles.headline: Maliki Agrees to Relinquish Power in Iraq
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki said Thursday he had agreed to step down, conceding to pressure from within Iraq and the United States and Iran.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki said Thursday he had agreed to step down, conceding to pressure from within Iraq and the United States and Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki said Thursday night that he had agreed to relinquish power, a move that came after days of crisis in which his deployment of extra security forces around the capital had raised worries of a military coup.

articles.headline: Why a Rule on Loan Losses Could Squeeze Credit
articles.snippet: A requirement that banks report potential loan losses immediately after making the loan could lead banks to suspend lending to improve earnings.
articles.abstract: A requirement that banks report potential loan losses immediately after making the loan could lead banks to suspend lending to improve earnings.
articles.lead_paragraph: No bank loses money on every loan, at least not if it is going to stay in business.

articles.headline: Web Trolls Winning as Incivility Increases
articles.snippet: Emotionally abusive comments are becoming more common online, and the consequences could include scaring away from the web those subject to attacks.
articles.abstract: Emotionally abusive comments are becoming more common online, and the consequences could include scaring away from the web those subject to attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Internet may be losing the war against trolls. At the very least, it isn’t winning. And unless social networks, media sites and governments come up with some innovative way of defeating online troublemakers, the digital world will never be free of the trolls’ collective sway.

articles.headline: Traders Profit as Power Grid Is Overworked
articles.snippet: Trading linked to congestion on New York State’s electric grid, a market intended to protect power companies and ultimately benefit consumers, has made big profits for trading firms.
articles.abstract: Trading linked to congestion on New York State’s electric grid, a market intended to protect power companies and ultimately benefit consumers, has made big profits for trading firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT JEFFERSON, N.Y. — By 10 a.m. the heat was closing in on the North Shore of Long Island. But 300 miles down the seaboard, at an obscure investment company near Washington, the forecast pointed to something else: profit.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: Pharmacies Turn Drugs Into Profits, Pitting Insurers vs. Compounders
articles.snippet: Alarmed by a rapid increase in spending on compounded drugs, like a $1,600 baby balm, insurers and others are acting to control their use.
articles.abstract: Alarmed by a rapid increase in spending on compounded drugs, like a $1,600 baby balm, insurers and others are acting to control their use.
articles.lead_paragraph: It may be the biggest thing in diaper rash treatment, a custom-made product to soothe a baby’s bottom at the eye-popping price of $1,600.

articles.headline: Fight Brews on Changes That Affect Derivatives
articles.snippet: While Wall Street is largely resigned to the regulators’ ultimately getting their way, it is nevertheless pressing for measures seen as protections in return.
articles.abstract: While Wall Street is largely resigned to the regulators’ ultimately getting their way, it is nevertheless pressing for measures seen as protections in return.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tensions are building in an enormous market that nearly brought Wall Street to its knees in 2008.

articles.headline: In Wake of Clashes, Calls to Demilitarize Police
articles.snippet: Images of billowing tear gas and explosions used in response to protests in Ferguson, Mo., have spurred a broad call from across the political spectrum for the demilitarization of police.
articles.abstract: Images of billowing tear gas and explosions used in response to protests in Ferguson, Mo., have spurred a broad call from across the political spectrum for the demilitarization of police.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — For four nights in a row, they streamed onto West Florissant Avenue wearing camouflage, black helmets and vests with “POLICE” stamped on the back. They carried objects that doubled as warnings: assault rifles and ammunition, slender black nightsticks and gas masks.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: A Ukraine City Under Siege, ‘Just Terrified of the Bombing’
articles.snippet: Life in Luhansk, Ukraine, is tough, but far from catastrophic. The only relief most people here seek is from the shelling, which goes on night and day.
articles.abstract: Life in Luhansk, Ukraine, is tough, but far from catastrophic. The only relief most people here seek is from the shelling, which goes on night and day.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUHANSK, Ukraine — Every night, as darkness falls over Luhansk, the focus now of intense humanitarian concern and geopolitical intrigue, a cat-and-mouse artillery duel begins.

articles.headline: Doubt Is Cast on Vetting of Deals by Alibaba
articles.snippet: On Friday, the company announced that it had discovered suspicious accounting at one of its acquisitions, a Hong Kong film company.
articles.abstract: On Friday, the company announced that it had discovered suspicious accounting at one of its acquisitions, a Hong Kong film company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:25 p.m. | The Alibaba Group, the Chinese e-commerce giant, has been on a buying spree since the start of last year, spending billions of dollars to acquire stakes in businesses like department stores and mapping services in China and an array of technology start-ups in the United States.

articles.headline: Emotions Flare in Missouri Amid Police Statements
articles.snippet: The manner in which the police identified the officer involved in the death of Michael Brown and released evidence that Mr. Brown was a suspect in a robbery renewed tension in the Missouri town.
articles.abstract: The manner in which the police identified the officer involved in the death of Michael Brown and released evidence that Mr. Brown was a suspect in a robbery renewed tension in the Missouri town.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — One day after roiling tensions over the police shooting of a black teenager here began to subside, emotions flared anew on Friday as the police identified the officer involved but also released evidence that the victim was a suspect in a convenience store robbery moments before being shot.
articles.byline: By Tanzina Vega, Timothy Williams and Erik Eckholm

articles.headline: Fears of Renewed Instability as Fed Ends Stimulus
articles.snippet: As the Fed feels its way, a former member of the Fed board said that investors may have to prepare for greater volatility.
articles.abstract: As the Fed feels its way, a former member of the Fed board said that investors may have to prepare for greater volatility.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a nearly uninterrupted five-year rally in stocks and bonds, some investors seem to be getting nervous. On July 31, the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 317 points, wiping out the year’s gains. Last week, junk bond funds experienced record withdrawals and junk bond interest rates spiked.

articles.headline: Lower Your Car Insurance Bill, at the Price of Some Privacy
articles.snippet: Usage-based insurance programs monitor your driving habits to see if you qualify for lower rates. The disadvantages are not insignificant, however.
articles.abstract: Usage-based insurance programs monitor your driving habits to see if you qualify for lower rates. The disadvantages are not insignificant, however.
articles.lead_paragraph: An increasing number of the nation’s auto insurance companies have a new proposition: Let them track every second of your driving in exchange for an annual discount that can reach into the hundreds of dollars if you behave yourself on the road.
